meanings.definition: Remedy or compensation for a wrong or grievance.
meanings.sent1: She sought redress for the unfair treatment she received at work.
meanings.sent2: The court ordered the company to provide redress to the victims of the scam.
meanings.sent3: The redress offered by the company included a sincere apology and financial compensation.
meanings.sent4: In the story, the hero seeks redress for the villagers who were wronged by the evil king.
meanings.sent5: The redress provided a sense of closure and justice to the affected families.

meanings.sent1: He tried to redress his mistake by apologizing to his friend.
meanings.sent2: The teacher helped the student redress the error in his math homework.
meanings.sent3: The magician used his wand to redress the rabbit back into a hat.
meanings.sent4: She hoped to redress the situation by offering a sincere explanation.
meanings.sent5: The mechanic worked diligently to redress the issue with the car's engine.

meanings.definition: To set right; remedy or repair.
meanings.sent1: The plumber was called to redress the leaky pipe in the kitchen.
meanings.sent2: The government promised to redress the issues affecting the healthcare system.
meanings.sent3: The superhero used his powers to redress the damage caused by the villain.
meanings.sent4: The artist worked tirelessly to redress the imperfections in the painting.
meanings.sent5: Efforts were made to redress the environmental damage caused by the industrial activities.
